In philosophy, "givenness" refers to the quality of something being "given" to us in our experience. It is the way in which things appear to us in our subjective experience, and is often associated with the phenomenological tradition in philosophy. The idea is that there are certain things in our experience that are simply given to us, without any need for further explanation or analysis.

For example, the color red might be considered a given in our experience. When we see something that is red, we simply perceive it as such without needing to question or analyze the experience. Similarly, the feeling of warmth from the sun might be considered a given in our experience, as it is something we simply experience without needing to analyze it further.

The concept of givenness is important in phenomenology because it emphasizes the subjective nature of our experience and the importance of taking our immediate experience seriously. By focusing on the givenness of our experience, we can gain a deeper understanding of the nature of consciousness and the way in which we perceive the world around us.

Facticity and givenness are related concepts, but they refer to slightly different aspects of our experience.

Givenness refers to the quality of something being "given" to us in our experience. It is the way in which things appear to us in our subjective experience. For example, the color red or the feeling of warmth from the sun might be considered a given in our experience.

Facticity, on the other hand, refers to the concrete, factual aspects of our existence. It includes things like our physical body, our social context, our historical situation, and so on. These are the things that are "factual" about our existence, in the sense that they cannot be changed or denied.

In the context of phenomenology, facticity and givenness are often discussed together, as they both contribute to our overall experience of the world. Our facticity shapes the way in which things are given to us, and our givenness shapes the way in which we experience our facticity. By examining both aspects of our experience, we can gain a deeper understanding of the nature of consciousness and the way in which we perceive the world around us.
what do you mean by eidetic reduction

Eidetic reduction is a method in phenomenology used to uncover the essential or necessary features of a given experience or object. The term "eidetic" comes from the Greek word "eidos," which means "essence" or "form."

In the context of phenomenology, eidetic reduction involves setting aside the particular or contingent aspects of an experience or object and focusing instead on its essential features. This involves a process of imaginative variation, in which one considers different possible variations of the experience or object in order to isolate the features that are necessary for its identity.

For example, in order to determine the essential features of the experience of seeing a tree, one might consider different variations of the experience, such as seeing the tree in different lighting conditions or from different angles. By doing so, one can isolate the features of the experience that are necessary for it to be the experience of seeing a tree, such as the visual perception of a vertical trunk and leafy branches.

Eidetic reduction is a key method in phenomenology because it allows us to uncover the essential structures of consciousness and the world, which are necessary for any meaningful experience or understanding. By identifying these essential structures, we can gain a deeper understanding of the nature of our experience and the world around us.

The term "immanent" is used in philosophy to refer to something that is inherent within a particular domain or context, rather than transcending it or existing outside of it. In other words, something that is immanent is present or contained within a particular system or realm, rather than existing as a separate or transcendent entity.

In the context of phenomenology, the term "immanent" is often used to describe the relationship between consciousness and the objects of consciousness. According to phenomenology, objects are not "out there" in the world waiting to be discovered, but are instead immanent within our experience. In other words, the objects of our experience are not external entities that we perceive from a distance, but are instead present within our consciousness, and are constituted by the acts of consciousness themselves.

For example, when we see a tree, the tree is not a separate object that exists outside of our perception, but is rather immanent within our experience of seeing. The tree is constituted by our perceptual acts, and is present within our experience in a way that is inseparable from our consciousness of it.

In this sense, the phenomenological approach emphasizes the immanent nature of experience, and seeks to understand the structures and processes of consciousness that allow us to constitute the objects of our experience in this way.
can you quote some important sayings from Husserls book about intention, method of reduction

Sure, here are some important quotes from Husserl's works on the topics of intentionality and the method of reduction:

On intentionality:

* "Every mental act is directed toward an object, every mental act intends something." (Logical Investigations, 1900-1901)
* "Consciousness is essentially intentional, meaning that it is always directed towards some object or content." (Ideas I, 1913)

On the method of reduction:

* "To the things themselves! Back to the things themselves!... We must be brought back to the most basic and primordial way of apprehending things, which is the way of pure intuition." (Ideas I, 1913)
* "The method of phenomenological reduction ... involves setting aside all assumptions about the objective reality of the world and focusing instead on the subjective experiences that give rise to our knowledge of that world." (Ideas II, 1952)
* "The goal of phenomenological reduction is to arrive at the essence of consciousness, which is the transcendental ego, the ultimate source of all meaning and intentionality." (Cartesian Meditations, 1931)
can you quote some important sayings from Husserls book about consciousness and experience

Sure, here are some important quotes from Husserl's works on the topics of consciousness and experience:

On consciousness:

* "Consciousness is always consciousness of something, it is essentially intentional." (Ideas I, 1913)
* "Consciousness is not an object or thing, but rather the very condition for the possibility of objects and things." (Ideas II, 1952)
* "Consciousness is an infinite horizon that cannot be exhausted by any finite experience." (Cartesian Meditations, 1931)

On experience:

* "Experience is the foundation of all knowledge, it is the primary source of all our beliefs and judgments." (Logical Investigations, 1900-1901)
* "Experience is always subjective, it is the subjective side of the world, and it cannot be reduced to objective facts or data." (Ideas I, 1913)
* "Experience is always a unity of intentionality, meaning that it is always directed towards some object or content." (Ideas II, 1952)
can you quote some important sayings from Husserls book about natural attitude

Here are some important quotes from Husserl's work regarding the natural attitude:

* "The natural standpoint of the everyday man is a pre-philosophical position which never becomes the subject of explicit reflection." (Ideas I, §38)
* "The natural attitude is the seat of all prejudices and errors." (The Crisis of European Sciences and Transcendental Phenomenology, p. 67)
* "The natural attitude posits the world as a realm of being independent of consciousness." (Ideas I, §33)
* "The natural attitude takes it for granted that things are just as they appear to us in perception." (The Crisis of European Sciences and Transcendental Phenomenology, p. 59)
* "The natural attitude fails to recognize the role of consciousness in the constitution of the world." (Ideas I, §38)

Can you explain subjectivity from his philosophy

Sure! In Sartre's philosophy, subjectivity is a central concept. He argues that human beings are fundamentally free and conscious subjects, and that this subjectivity is what gives meaning to the world.

Sartre begins with the observation that human beings experience themselves as conscious, free, and self-aware. This subjective experience of the world is what gives meaning to our lives, and allows us to make choices and take actions in the world. Sartre argues that this subjective experience is what defines us as human beings, and that it is the source of all value and meaning in our lives.

At the same time, Sartre is also critical of the ways in which people often deny or suppress their subjectivity. He argues that many people live their lives in what he calls the "bad faith" - that is, they deny their own freedom and responsibility, and instead try to live as if they were mere objects in the world. This, according to Sartre, is a form of self-deception that prevents people from living authentic lives.

Overall, Sartre's philosophy emphasizes the importance of subjective experience and the need for individuals to take responsibility for their own lives and choices. It is a philosophy that celebrates the freedom and creativity of human beings, while also recognizing the challenges and responsibilities that come with this freedom.
